results.title: Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation and Karl Kruszelnicki
results.brief_description: Dr Karl Kruszelnicki presents four programs which attempt to de-mystify some of the great questions in science. All are presented chiefly in animation, and all manage to unravel the mystery in under 6 minutes.
results.title_for_label: Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki

results.title: Murphy's law
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation and Karl Kruszelnicki
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
If there are two or more ways to do something and if one of those results in catastrophe, then someone will do it that way, Edward A. Murphy Jr. In 1949 the US Airforce had a project called MX984 which measured G forces and in which Edward A. Murphy was working. You can find out what went wrong and how inadvertently this famous law came about. With the use of several animation techniques, Karl Kruszelnicki explains this, as well as why a falling piece of toast will always land on the floor - buttered side down.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation and Karl Kruszelnicki

results.title: Arrow up yours
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Aninmation and Karl Kruszelnicki
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
This entertaining animation presented by Karl Kruszelnicki explains the bow and arrow and its history and in so doing provides an explanation for the well known two finger salute. There is mention of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, and how the well trained British used the Welsh long bow to attack the French. All this adds up to the reason behind the two finger salute.

results.title: Manhole cover: first in space
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation and Karl Kruszelnicki
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
Was the first manmade object in space the Sputnik? No, it was an American Manhole cover. In this animation, Karl Kruszelnicki explains why. He talks of satellites and nuclear testing both above and below ground. This entertaining and educational short animation will fill you in.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation and Karl Kruszelnicki

results.title: Falling cats
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro and Lilyfield Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
It is safer for a cat to fall from a thirty-two story building than a seven story building and testing these things are easy in the ready made environment of New York and its high rise. It is said that one hundred and thirty two cats in five months fall from high rise buildings. Lots of information has been gathered, and it had been found that ninety percent of cats survive. In fact, the higher the building, the higher the chance of survival, the shorter the distance, the greater the chance of broken bones. Find out more in this animation, it is very interesting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro and Lilyfield Productions

group_works.title: Alma de Groen
group_works.creator_credit: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland

results.title: Alma de Groen
results.creator_credit: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Alma De Groen is one of Australia’s most innovative and challenging playwrights. This interview offers an enlightening introduction to her work. She speaks about her early plays and the emergence of her interest in the outsider figure, feminism, and developments in her latest work. She also discusses the inspiration she seeks from the work of visual artists for the form and style of her plays. Interviewed by Elizabeth Perkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland

results.title: Jack Hibberd
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
An interview with Australian playwright Jack Hibberd by Paul McGillick. Jack Hibberd’s plays have been characterised by great comic invention and an exploration of theatrical forms.

results.title: Stephen Sewell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Stephen Sewell’s plays have often aroused considerable controversy over their moral and political exploration. He discusses the influence of his Catholic, working-class background on his work.

results.title: David Williamson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Without a question Australia’s most popular and successful playwright is David Williamson. He has analysed and mythologised Australia in thirteen professionally performed plays.
